<title
    level="1"
    right="Feat 2"
    pfs="Standard"
>
[Backup Disguise](/Feats.aspx?ID=1064) <actions string="" />
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Uncommon" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=159" />
<trait label="General" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=78" />
<trait label="Skill" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=144" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Character Guide](/Sources.aspx?ID=12) pg. 71 <sup>2.0</sup></row>

**Prerequisites**
Expert in [Deception](/Skills.aspx?ID=5)

**Access**
members of the Firebrands gain access to them once they reach the rank of second mark

</column>

---

You have a specific disguise that you keep at the ready, worn underneath your outer garment. You can change into this disguise to [Impersonate](/Actions.aspx?ID=46) as a 3-action activity. If you have master proficiency in Deception, it is instead a 2-action activity, and if you have legendary proficiency, it is a single action. You can create a new backup disguise by spending the normal amount of time it takes you to Impersonate, but you can have only one backup disguise at a time. Having a backup disguise doesn’t allow you to remove your armor or any other complex piece of clothing any more quickly, but once you have those off, the disguise is readily available. Because you have the backup disguise at the ready, it’s possible that a thorough search might reveal some elements of the disguise (see [Conceal an Object](/Actions.aspx?ID=61) in the [Stealth](/Skills.aspx?ID=15) skill).

<title level="2">Firebrand Options</title>

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Character Guide](/Sources.aspx?ID=12) pg. 71 <sup>2.0</sup></row>

The Firebrands use a variety of unorthodox equipment and techniques to achieve their goals, whether those goals include drawing attention, or subterfuge and subtlety. The following Firebrand options are uncommon, and members of the Firebrands gain access to them once they reach the rank of second mark. The [Entourage](/Feats.aspx?ID=1066) feat is rare even for members of the Firebrands, as it requires a certain degree of fame and in-world activity to acquire, and potentially requires the player or GM to keep track of additional background NPCs. Typically, only third mark and fourth mark Firebrands have the notoriety and social influence required to maintain an entourage. While Firebrands seek to build an entourage more than most adventurers, it’s not unreasonable for any famous character to gain access to it if the players are interested in playing with the [Entourage](/Feats.aspx?ID=1066) feat.

**Related Feats**: [Entourage](/Feats.aspx?ID=1066), [Sow Rumor](/Feats.aspx?ID=1065)
